This act, Poole notes, is deeply covenantal: Jacob's promise of land and blessing to his descendants (Genesis 48:4) finds fulfillment through this adoption, ensuring the promise remains active despite Rachel's death and the family's Egyptian exile. Crucially, Poole interprets Jacob's ritual of placing his right hand on the younger Ephraim's head (Genesis 48:14) as a divine sign of prophetic authority. This deliberate reversal of birthright order, where the younger receives the greater honor, prefigures Christ's spiritual supremacy—Ephraim becoming the "firstborn" in the New Covenant, while Manasseh represents the established order. Theologically, this underscores God's sovereignty over lineage and blessing, where divine purpose transcends human hierarchy. Practically, it teaches believers to actively pursue God's blessing on the younger generation, recognizing that spiritual inheritance flows through Christ's redemptive work, not merely bloodline. For modern readers, this passage calls for humility in family relationships and intentional blessing of others, especially the vulnerable, while reminding us that Christ's authority—exalted as the "firstborn of every creature" (Ephesians 1:22)—trumps all earthly claims to leadership. Poole's insight that Jacob's blessing was both paternal and prophetic encourages us to see Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of God's promises to Abraham, binding us to a family where divine sovereignty is honored through faithful discipleship. Albert Barnes's commentary on Genesis 48 reveals profound theological depth in Jacob's final blessing of Joseph's sons. As Jacob, weakened by age, blesses Ephraim and Manasseh—placing his right hand on the younger—Barnes emphasizes this deliberate act as a divine appointment, not a natural preference. Jacob's blessing explicitly articulates the triune nature of God: the "God before whom my fathers walked" (the covenantal Creator), the "God who fed me" (the sustaining Redeemer), and the "Angel who redeemed me" (Christ himself, the agent of salvation). This threefold blessing prefigures Christ's dual role as both the spiritual head of the church and the fulfillment of the Abrahamic promise. Barnes notes Joseph's protest over the hand placement, highlighting how Jacob's action intentionally elevates Ephraim—a symbolic foreshadowing of Christ's spiritual authority surpassing natural birth order. Practically, this passage urges believers to prioritize spiritual maturity and divine calling over natural lineage when discerning blessing. It challenges us to actively cultivate the "multitude" of God's kingdom through faithful discipleship, not merely numerical growth. Christologically, Ephraim becomes the New Testament symbol of the church, where Christ, the true "firstborn" (Col 1:15), receives the greater blessing through faith. This scene teaches that true inheritance comes through Christ's work, not human hierarchy, encouraging believers to bless the spiritually gifted while honoring God's sovereign design in family and kingdom.

Matthew Henry's commentary on Genesis 49 reveals Jacob's prophetic blessing as a divine blueprint for Israel's future, transcending familial affection to disclose God's sovereign plan for the tribes. Henry emphasizes that Jacob's words are not personal sentiment but the Holy Spirit's revelation of God's purpose for each tribe's character, circumstances, and destiny within the covenant community. Reuben's instability and sin, Simeon and Levi's violent temper (foreshadowing the murder of Shechem), and the curse on their "anger" serve as stark warnings against moral corruption and vengeance, highlighting that true honor stems from righteous living, not destructive impulses. Judah's prominent role—described as a lion's whelp, the scepter's keeper, and the lineage of Shiloh—holds profound Christological significance: Henry explicitly connects Judah to the Messiah, declaring that "the sceptre shall not depart from Judah" until Christ's coming, identifying Shiloh as the promised Savior who brings peace and redemption. This prophecy becomes the theological anchor for understanding Christ's role as the true vine and the fulfillment of all blessing. Practically, Henry urges believers to reject Reuben's instability (sinful wandering), avoid Simeon-Levi's vengeance, embrace Judah's example of peaceful authority, and recognize their own unique gifts (like Zebulun's trade or Naphtali's agility) as instruments for God's kingdom. The commentary thus transforms ancient tribal prophecies into living applications: Christians are called to live with Christ-like restraint, pursue spiritual nourishment through His blood (the "wine"), and find hope in the promised Seed who ultimately gathers all people into eternal life.

Calvin's commentary on Genesis 49 reveals Jacob's prophetic blessing as a divine blueprint for Israel's future, emphasizing God's sovereign orchestration of salvation history. Calvin highlights how the "stone of Israel" (v24) symbolizes Christ as the foundational rock of God's people, while Joseph's blessing (v22-26) underscores the kingly authority of the Messiah who would bless "beneath the heavens" and "the deep." Theologically, Calvin stresses that Jacob's words expose God's judgment on sin (e.g., Reuben's betrayal, Simeon and Levi's violence) while simultaneously affirming His redemptive purpose across all tribes. Practically, believers are called to avoid the pitfalls Jacob warns—such as pride and uncontrolled anger—by cultivating humility and obedience. Christ's fulfillment of Judah's blessing provides the ultimate hope: the Messiah who "shall come" (v10) brings reconciliation and authority, urging Christians to live as faithful stewards of God's promises. Calvin concludes that this passage demonstrates God's eternal covenant faithfulness, where every tribe's role points toward Christ, challenging believers to seek His kingdom and righteousness in daily life while trusting in His ultimate redemption. Poole emphasizes Jacob's final blessing in Genesis 49 as a profound theological warning and prophetic revelation, where Jacob confronts his sons' moral failures while foretelling God's future work. He meticulously interprets Reuben's sin—his incest with Bilhah—as a catastrophic example of how pride and moral compromise destroy divine favor, rendering Reuben "unstable as water" and destined for spiritual dispersion, a caution against prioritizing personal ambition over covenant integrity. Similarly, Poole highlights Simeon and Levi's violent actions in Genesis 34 as a warning against alliances built on bloodshed and deceit, where their "contracts" (nuptial agreements) became instruments of cruelty, urging believers to avoid complicity in destructive schemes. Crucially, Poole focuses on Judah's blessing as Christ's direct foreshadowing: Judah's "scepter" and "covenant with the Gentiles" explicitly point to Christ's kingly authority and the inclusion of non-Jewish peoples in God's redemptive plan. This theological insight reveals that Christ's coming fulfills the promise of a new covenant where divine grace transcends ethnic boundaries. Practically, Poole's commentary challenges believers to examine their own "secret" alliances and actions—avoiding the sinfulness of Reuben and the violence of Simeon/Levi—while actively embracing Judah's hope: living in Christ's kingdom requires rejecting worldly divisions and actively participating in God's work of blessing the nations. This Christ-centered application calls us to moral vigilance and inclusive love, ensuring our faith remains rooted in divine promises rather than human failure.

Albert Barnes's commentary on Genesis 49 emphasizes Jacob's prophetic blessing as a covenantal revelation shaping Israel's future, revealing profound theological truths about identity and divine purpose. Barnes interprets Jacob's call to his sons not merely as a family gathering but as a divine instruction for the entire human race, framing the "after days" as the period between creation and the new heavens and earth. The distinction between "Jacob" (the natural, earthly covenant) and "Israel" (the spiritual, redeemed community) underscores the covenant's transformative nature. Barnes meticulously traces the blessings: Reuben's forfeiture due to impurity, Simeon and Levi's scattering from their violent pride, and Judah's supremacy as the "rod" of God, directly pointing to Christ. Crucially, Barnes connects Judah's blessing—where "the hand shall be in the neck of thine enemies" and "thy father's children shall bow down to thee"—to Christology, identifying this as the prophetic foundation for Jesus, the Messiah from Judah who would rule over enemies and establish God's kingdom. Theologically, this highlights how the patriarchal blessings foreshadow the New Covenant, where Christ's lineage unites the divided tribes into one people. Practically, believers are called to avoid Reuben's pattern of sin, reject Simeon and Levi's vengeful anger, and embrace Judah's spirit of authoritative, loving leadership. This commentary challenges modern readers to recognize their identity in Christ (the spiritual Israel), cultivate integrity in relationships, and actively participate in God's redemptive work—knowing that the blessing of Judah remains the ultimate promise of Christ's coming reign. Henry observes that Joseph's burial of his father Jacob in Genesis 50 exemplifies profound theological principles and practical Christian living. Joseph's actions—embalming Jacob, mourning for forty days, and fulfilling his father's vow to be buried in Canaan—reveal how faith in God's promises moderates natural grief while preparing believers for resurrection hope. Henry emphasizes that Joseph's death at 110, accompanied by his command to carry his bones to Canaan, foreshadows Christ's resurrection power: just as Joseph's bones were to await the promise of Canaan, Christ's resurrection body now fulfills the promise of eternal life. Theologically, this scene illustrates God's sovereignty in redemption—Joseph's brothers' fear of vengeance was transformed by Christ-like forgiveness, showing that God uses human failures for good (Genesis 50:20). Practically, it encourages believers to comfort others with hope, forgive as Joseph did, and maintain steadfast trust in God's promises even amid grief. When we face loss or perceived betrayal, we are called to model Joseph's response: address fears with Christ-centered assurance, pursue reconciliation, and anchor hope in God's ultimate purpose. This narrative underscores that true faith transforms sorrow into purpose, demonstrating that Christ's victory over death enables us to live with confidence, knowing our ultimate home is with God. As Joseph's bones await Canaan, so too do we await Christ's return, where death's finality is conquered by resurrection life. (247 words)

John Calvin's commentary on Genesis 50 emphasizes the profound theological significance of Joseph's final acts after his father Jacob's death. Calvin observes that Joseph's immediate physical response—falling upon his father's face, weeping, and kissing him—demonstrates pure, unfeigned love and filial devotion, contrasting sharply with the Egyptian mourning practices that, while ceremonial, lacked genuine sorrow. This scene reveals the covenantal depth of Joseph's relationship with his father, fulfilling Jacob's earlier promise to bury him in Canaan. Calvin connects this to Christ by noting how Joseph's ultimate burial in Egypt (as a temporary resting place) prefigures Christ's own death and resurrection, where the "cave of the field of Machpelah" becomes the spiritual reality of the tomb. Theologically, Calvin stresses that Joseph's obedience to his father's command—despite his immense power—exemplifies the covenant loyalty required of God's people. Practically, this narrative instructs believers to honor family bonds with sacrificial love, even when facing cultural or political pressures, and to view mourning not as despair but as an act of faith that honors God's promises. Joseph's final words to his brethren—"God will surely visit you and bring you out of this land"—point to Christ's ultimate fulfillment of the Abrahamic covenant, where the promise of blessing and restoration is realized through Christ's death and resurrection, ensuring the Israelites' return to their ancestral land. Thus, Calvin teaches that Joseph's story is a prefiguration of Christ's redemptive mission, urging believers to live with humble obedience and confident hope in God's faithful promises. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Genesis 50 reveals profound theological depth in Joseph's final acts following his father Jacob's death. He meticulously details Joseph's compliance with Jacob's burial command, emphasizing the solemnity of this promise: Joseph embalmed his father using Egyptian customs (to honor his father while facilitating the journey), secured Pharaoh's permission, and led a large procession to Canaan, where his brothers and household mourned intensely for seven days—a practice reflecting the cultural weight of covenantal obligations. Poole highlights how this ritual underscores God's faithfulness in preserving family identity across cultures and time, as Joseph honored his father's specific request for burial in Canaan despite Egyptian customs. Theologically, this passage demonstrates that God's promises endure even in death, with Joseph's obedience becoming a living testament to covenantal loyalty. Practically, it challenges believers to honor parental legacies and sacred oaths with the same gravity Joseph applied, urging careful stewardship of family commitments and cultural sensitivity during mourning. Crucially, Poole connects this narrative to Christ: the embalming process (preserving the body for resurrection) and the 70-day mourning period (a timeframe echoing Christ's resurrection) prefigure Christ's own burial and resurrection. Joseph's assurance of his brethren's future return to Canaan also echoes Christ's promise of restoration for His people. Thus, this chapter reveals how God uses human obedience to foreshadow Christ's victory, urging believers to approach grief and covenant with both reverence and hope.

Albert Barnes's commentary on Genesis 50 emphasizes Joseph's profound obedience to his father's covenant promise and the profound theological significance of his actions. After his father Jacob's death, Joseph meticulously followed Egyptian customs—embalming the body for forty days and observing a seventy-day mourning period—while simultaneously securing Pharaoh's permission to bury his father in Canaan as he had sworn. This demonstrates Joseph's unwavering commitment to honoring his father's faithfulness to God, even amidst immense political power. Crucially, Barnes highlights how Joseph's response to his brothers' fear after his father's death reveals a deeper theological truth: Joseph reframes their past betrayal as part of God's redemptive plan ("God meant it unto good... to save much people alive"). This act of forgiveness becomes a powerful model for practical Christian living, teaching believers to overcome resentment through Christ-centered perspective, recognizing that God's purposes often transcend human understanding. Theologically, Joseph's story foreshadows Christ's role as the ultimate fulfillment of covenant promises—his burial in Canaan (as a type) parallels Christ's burial in the tomb, and his forgiveness prefigures Christ's atoning work that reconciles sinners. Practically, this passage urges believers to address grief with purpose, honor ancestral covenants, and extend grace to those who have wronged us, trusting that God's design for healing and restoration operates through faith. Joseph's life thus reveals how obedience to God's word, even in profound loss, points toward the hope of resurrection and eternal restoration through Christ. (248 words)
